name: Ms. Iris Bookwright
description: A middle-aged woman with graying auburn hair in a bob that's just tidy enough while not seeming like it's paid a lot of attention. She wears a blouse and a skirt that clearly has multiple pockets stuffed with index cards and a magnifying glass. Her thoughtful eyes peer over half-moon reading glasses that dangle from a beaded chain.
background: Head librarian of the Environmental Science Library. Organizes books by their 'preferred habitat' and believes in bibliofungal symbiosis.

library_map.description: A folded paper sticking out of her jacket pocket, covered in her distinctive purple ink.

mycelial_tea.description: A steaming earthenware mug with small mushroom designs etched into it sits on her desk.

rare_books_key.description: An ornate brass key hanging from a chain on her belt, alongside several index cards bound with rubber bands.

special_items.name: Hand-drawn Library Map
special_items.description: A map with moisture warnings, showing how book sections shift with humidity

special_items.name: Rare Books Request Form
special_items.description: Required 48 hours in advance to view special collection materials

special_items.name: Ripples Through Time
special_items.description: A book that leaves your hands slightly damp

Professor Moss.description: They discuss fungal literature and share similar quirky worldviews about nature's intelligence.

Students.description: Helps students navigate both the library and the interconnected web of environmental knowledge.

rare_collection_access.description: Trusted enough to see the rare collection and hear about the Great Spore Incident.

enhanced_reading.description: Experienced the mild hallucination effects of mushroom tea, seeing shimmering text.

storm_responsive_texts.description: Learned about books that change during thunderstorms and the student who tried to read them.

ambient_behaviors: adjusts books that are 'arguing' with each other
checks humidity levels with hand-held sensor
whispers to books while shelving them
traces spore dispersal patterns in the air
